title: R42389
content: Child support is a cash payment that noncustodial parents must pay for their children's financial support. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program, established in 1975, aims to secure consistent financial support for children from their noncustodial parent and promote self-sufficiency for families. The program is based on the idea that both parents are financially responsible for their children, with states administering it and the federal government playing a significant role in program design and funding. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program plays a major role in designing state programs, funding, monitoring, and evaluating them, providing technical assistance, and helping locate noncustodial parents for child support payments. States use various methods, including the threat of jail or actual incarceration, to collect child support. Noncustodial parents who fail to pay may face civil or criminal charges, as all states have statutes related to child support nonpayment. Failure to pay child support is considered a crime under state criminal nonsupport statutes, but some states may treat it as a violation of a court order, known as contempt of court. The CSE program allows caseworkers to use various methods to collect child support, and they have the authority to issue a warrant for noncompliant noncustodial parents. The task of persuading noncustodial parents to pay child support is often futile for judges, who resort to the threat of jail as leverage. About 70% of child support arrearages are owed by noncustodial parents with little to no income, making it a constant problem. Data on the frequency of incarceration for nonpayment is lacking. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program operates in all 50 states and provides various services for children, including parent location, paternity establishment, and collection of child support payments. Collection methods include income withholding and intercept of tax refunds. Data on the frequency of incarceration for nonpayment of child support is lacking. State CSE agencies have various enforcement methods such as income withholding, intercepting tax refunds, liens on property, reporting to credit bureaus, intercepting lottery winnings, and seizing assets from retirement funds. They also have the authority to suspend licenses and passports of parents who owe child support. Federal law mandates states to enact UIFSA for interstate cases and provides for international enforcement of child support. Federal law allows for international enforcement of child support and imposes federal criminal penalties in certain cases. All jurisdictions have procedures for civil or criminal contempt-of-court and criminal nonsupport laws. States can incarcerate noncustodial parents who owe past-due child support. The most effective enforcement tool is income withholding, with 67% of child support payments collected through this method in FY2010. Other methods include intercepting tax refunds, unemployment benefits, and seizing assets. Based on sporadic data from the federal Office of Child Support Enforcement (OCSE), roughly $3.5 billion of child support collections come from financial institutions, while about $1 billion is from collections obtained through driver's license suspension. Less than 2% of child support collections are associated with the threat of incarceration. If a noncustodial parent is incarcerated for nonpayment, the likelihood of receiving child support during that time is very small. States have enforced child support through various methods, including income withholding, intercepting tax refunds, and seizing assets. Before the enactment of the CSE program in 1975, states attempted to address the issue of nonpayment of child support. In 1910, the Uniform Desertion and Non-Support Act imposed penalties on fathers who failed to support their children. The 1950 Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act aimed to improve enforcement for noncustodial parents living in different states. The Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act (URESA) aimed to improve and extend the enforcement of child support duties through criminal and civil enforcement. It was recognized that putting noncustodial parents in jail was counterproductive as it burdened the state with supporting the family and hindered the parent's ability to find employment. The commissioners decided to keep criminal enforcement in the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act, as it was seen as a traditional method to address noncustodial parents who do not pay child support. State and federal laws penalizing non-paying parents have gained support, categorizing them as "can't pay" or "won't pay" parents. Policymakers and the public are sympathetic to those who cannot pay but are frustrated with those who refuse to pay. States and the federal government have implemented aggressive child support enforcement tools to pursue parents who refuse to pay despite having the means to do so. Criminal statutes and contempt of court orders are increasingly used in child support cases to address non-paying parents. Other countries, like England and Wales, also use jail as an option for nonresident parents who refuse to pay child maintenance. The Child Support Agency can seek a warrant of commitment to send nonresident parents to prison for up to six weeks if they refuse to pay child maintenance. Some countries, like Australia and Finland, do not imprison individuals for failing to pay child support. Denmark, although it specifies imprisonment, has never actually prosecuted or incarcerated anyone for nonpayment. The CSE program offers services for reviewing and modifying child support orders to ensure effectiveness. Nonpayment of child support can lead to a noncustodial parent being incarcerated under certain circumstances, such as contempt of court or prosecution under state criminal statutes. Low-income noncustodial parents are often jailed for nonpayment or contempt charges. Parents can be incarcerated for nonpayment of child support or contempt of court charges related to nonpayment. National data on the frequency of this option are lacking, as CSE agencies and law enforcement offices do not consistently track arrests for nonpayment. Contempt of court occurs when individuals violate court orders, with state courts having the authority to punish such behavior. Contempt can include acts that undermine the court's authority or obstruct justice, leading to potential incarceration. The court has the power to declare a defiant person in contempt, which can be civil or criminal. Civil contempt occurs when someone willfully disobeys a court order, and the individual may be fined or jailed to coerce compliance. In family law, civil contempt is used to enforce child support orders that have been violated. In civil contempt, courts enforce child support orders by potentially sending the noncustodial parent to jail until payment is made. Compliance with court requirements ends the contempt, while criminal contempt involves interfering with court functioning. Criminal contempt of court involves actions that disrupt court proceedings, such as yelling at the judge or jury. Offenders may face fines, jail time, or both as punishment. These charges are separate from the underlying case and can persist even after its resolution. It can be challenging to classify contempt as civil or criminal, and judges must carefully consider which type of contempt to impose. The parties agree that judges should carefully determine whether to impose civil or criminal contempt of court rulings to avoid wrongful incarceration. Civil contempt actions are typically against noncustodial parents with poor child support payment histories, aiming to encourage compliance with the support order by forcing the parent to pay. A finding of current ability to pay is usually required for a civil contempt ruling. The purpose of civil contempt actions against noncustodial parents is to enforce compliance with child support orders through coercive fines, compensatory fines, or incarceration. Sanctions must benefit the custodial parent and children, and the parent can avoid punishment by meeting specified requirements. In cases where the parent complies with the order, they are considered purged of contempt and free from further consequences. Some commentators argue that civil contempt actions against noncustodial parents may lead to unintended consequences, as some parents who are unable to pay child support obligations may still be charged with contempt of court. The burden of proving inability to pay is often placed on the defendant, and strict penal sanctions should only be imposed when the defendant is provided with due process rights. A strictly penal sanction should only be imposed when essential due process protections are provided, including notice of the offense, the right to present a defense, call witnesses, an impartial judge, and possibly counsel and a trial by jury. Criminal contempt proceedings are more complex than civil contempt proceedings, with formal notice requirements and the potential for an indigency hearing, jury trial, and change of judge. Despite the lengthy process, criminal contempt may be necessary in cases where a noncustodial parent repeatedly fails to make child support payments. When a noncustodial parent repeatedly fails to make child support payments, a criminal contempt action may be necessary. This can result in consecutive jail terms for multiple contempt of court rulings. Criminal contempt may be the only remedy for a parent who willingly limits their ability to pay child support out of spite. Unlike civil proceedings, criminal contempt does not always provide the same constitutional protections for the defendant. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to rule that due process requires legal representation for indigent noncustodial parents facing imprisonment for noncompliance with child support orders in Turner v. Rogers. The decision was based on the existence of procedural safeguards such as notice of the defendant's ability to pay and the use of financial information forms. The case involved a South Carolina child support issue where the defendant, Michael Turner, spent a year in jail for failing to pay child support without legal representation. The court did not make a finding on his ability to pay or indigent status. The jail time was a means to induce payment of nearly $6,000 in past-due child support. The Court relied on factors from Mathews v. Eldridge to determine necessary safeguards. The Court in the case of Mathews v. Eldridge determined that providing counsel to noncustodial parents in child support cases could create unfairness and delays in proceedings, potentially leading to erroneous decisions that deprive families of support. The Court emphasized the importance of considering the needs of families in such cases and highlighted the straightforward nature of child support proceedings, lack of representation by custodial parents, and existence of other procedural safeguards. The Court found that the lower court violated Turner's rights by not ensuring he had counsel or other procedural safeguards for determining his ability to pay child support. This decision did not address cases involving owed child support to the state or complex matters. Debate in the Turner v. Rogers case centered on whether nonpaying noncustodial parents should be labeled as deadbeats or not. Some noncustodial parents with high child support arrearages are seen as deadbeats who believe their obligations end with the relationship. Others withhold support to control their ex-spouses. Jail time is often the only way to make them comply. Low-income parents are sometimes viewed as "turnips" from whom no money can be squeezed. The majority of low-income noncustodial parents who end up in jail are those who cannot afford to pay child support. They are often referred to as "turnips" and are deprived of their freedom and job opportunities. In civil contempt cases, the defendant can end jail time by complying with the order, but lack of funds and legal representation can lead to imprisonment for debt they cannot pay. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to grant civil contempt defendants the right to counsel, leading to inequality in the justice system for custodial parents. However, the Court found that imprisoning individuals without determining their ability to pay violated their constitutional rights. This decision overturned a ruling by the South Carolina Supreme Court. The U.S. Supreme Court overturned a ruling by the South Carolina Supreme Court and sent the case back for further proceedings. Child Support Enforcement (CSE) actions may lead to criminal charges for delinquent obligors at state and federal levels. States have specific criminal statutes for failure to pay child support, with some allowing child support attorneys to file criminal charges. Other states have a referral process to review cases for criminal charges. The child support attorney may refer the case to the district attorney for criminal prosecution. Some states appoint child support attorneys as special prosecutors for this purpose. Criminal nonsupport proceedings can serve as a deterrent to noncompliance when civil remedies have been exhausted. Criminal charges can be effective in cases where civil remedies have failed or the noncustodial parent has been evading them. The usual rules of evidence apply in criminal nonsupport actions. The process of initiating criminal action for nonpayment of child support involves filing a complaint or indictment, obtaining a warrant or summons from a judge, and ensuring that all elements of the crime are alleged in a way that allows the defendant to understand the charge. State law defines these elements, and the standard of proof is proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Research in the early 1990s showed that some noncustodial parents intentionally chose not to meet their child support obligations, with increased chances of evasion when crossing state lines. The Child Support Recovery Act of 1992 addressed this issue. The Child Support Recovery Act of 1992 (P.L. 102-521) aimed to prevent parents from moving across state lines to avoid paying child support. It imposed federal criminal penalties for willful nonpayment of child support obligations to out-of-state children. The legislation targeted interstate cases, especially those involving parents who blatantly refuse to pay. Penalties included fines up to $5,000, imprisonment for up to six months, or both for first convictions, with harsher penalties for subsequent convictions. The Child Support Recovery Act of 1992 imposed federal criminal penalties for willful nonpayment of child support obligations to out-of-state children, with fines up to $5,000, imprisonment for up to six months, or both for first convictions. The Deadbeat Parents Punishment Act of 1998 established two new categories of felony offenses for more serious instances of nonpayment of child support obligations. The Deadbeat Parents Punishment Act of 1998 (P.L. 105-187) created two new felony offenses for failing to pay child support obligations. The offenses involve evading support payments over a certain amount or for a specific period. "Project Save Our Children" is the initiative that enforces these federal penalties, aiming to collect overdue child support from delinquent parents through collaboration between various government agencies and law enforcement. Project Save Our Children aims to increase child support collections by identifying and prosecuting delinquent offenders. In FY2006, the program received over 10,000 cases, resulting in 986 arrests and $35.8 million collected in restitution. In FY2007, $8.1 million was collected from 1,139 cases. The threat of jail often compels noncustodial parents to comply with child support orders, especially those with income or assets. Low-income noncustodial parents who cannot afford to pay child support may end up in jail as they lack the funds to comply with the threat. Despite the intention to coerce payment, many parents do not have the means to meet their obligations, leading to incarceration. Analysts argue that while the threat of jail can be a useful tool, actually following through may not be productive, especially for those without the financial resources to eliminate the threat. Putting low-income noncustodial parents in jail for unpaid child support may not be effective, as many are unemployed and unable to pay. Noncustodial fathers feel the Child Support Enforcement (CSE) system ignores their financial struggles and benefits the government more than their children. This leads to conflicts with the child's mother and does not necessarily improve the child's well-being. Noncustodial parents face conflicts with their child's mother over unpaid child support, often threatened with reporting to CSE authorities or jail. Commentators argue that jails can turn nonviolent individuals aggressive. Jails hold various offenders, including probation and parole violators, some of whom are violent. According to reports, violence is a common and accepted part of prison life, with high rates of physical assault among inmates. Many believe that jails and prisons should primarily house violent offenders, while non-violent offenders should be given less harsh alternatives. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) highlights the devastating effects of incarceration on men. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) reports that incarceration has a devastating impact on individuals who are poor, especially in terms of legal financial obligations. Even after release, those with unpaid legal debts face barriers to re-entering society, such as reduced income, worsened credit ratings, and limited housing and employment opportunities. This can increase their chances of returning to jail or prison. Many individuals struggle to balance their needs and legal financial obligations (LFOs) after release from incarceration. They face constant threats of being sent back to jail due to unmanageable legal debts, leading to stress and negative impacts on their mental and physical health. Some resort to self-medication with drugs, both inside and outside of jail, which can further strain parent-child relationships. The United States incarcerates more individuals than any other nation, with high costs exceeding $65 billion per year. To address budget constraints and overcrowding, many states are turning to alternatives like community service, halfway houses, and electronic monitoring as alternatives to jail. Many policy analysts argue that incarcerating individuals for nonviolent offenses like nonpayment of child support is counterproductive. They believe criminalizing nonpayment disproportionately affects low-income noncustodial parents, especially African Americans. CSE officials argue that noncustodial parents are penalized for being "deadbeats" and not for being poor, emphasizing the importance of demonstrating intent to avoid jail. Some noncustodial parents have a chance to avoid jail by demonstrating efforts to pay child support, such as seeking employment or proving low income. Being unable to pay due to poverty can still lead to incarceration, even if not intentional. Many noncustodial parents face incarceration for failing to pay child support due to unemployment or poverty. They believe their fate lies in the hands of CSE caseworkers who can issue warrants for their arrest without exploring all options first. Noncustodial parents facing jail for unpaid child support cannot substitute jail time for payments and often lack legal representation. Critics argue that incarceration harms parent-child relationships, impacting children's well-being. Noncustodial parents facing incarceration for unpaid child support may struggle to find employment due to their criminal record, leading to a cycle of financial hardship. Some suggest mandating work or training programs as an alternative to jail. Critics argue that the social, psychological, and emotional impacts on families and communities should be considered in addition to the financial costs of incarceration. Noncustodial parents who can't pay child support may request a modification or negotiate a payment plan with the CSE agency. Failure to pay child support leads to reduced income for children. Some argue that nonpayment should be a crime and result in incarceration, despite the cost. Incarceration is a tool used by state CSE agencies to enforce child support obligations, despite the availability of other enforcement tools. Policymakers believed that the threat of jail would compel noncustodial parents to pay their child support debts. The CSE program uses incarceration as a last resort for noncustodial parents who fail to pay child support, with all states having criminal sanctions for nonpayment. Noncustodial parents often try to avoid their obligations by hiding or working in the underground economy. The CSE program has become more effective in locating noncustodial parents and their income. Many noncustodial parents end up in jail due to inability to pay child support, not out of spite. Large caseloads lead to noncustodial parents being viewed as unreliable in their reasons for nonpayment. Many low-income noncustodial parents may end up in jail for nonpayment of child support, despite being unable to pay. Observers argue that incarcerating them is costly and hinders their future job prospects. Custodial parents acknowledge that some noncustodial parents are financially struggling, but caution against lowering child support orders, as it could impact families' ability to move out of poverty. The importance of not lowering child support orders, even for noncustodial parents in financial distress, is emphasized to prevent children from suffering due to unpaid support. The National Child Support Enforcement Strategic Plan aims to intervene early to prevent the accumulation of unpaid support, rather than relying on severe enforcement measures when it's too late for effective collection. The CSE Strategic Plan aims to build a culture of compliance among parents to support their children voluntarily. Ways to strengthen the system include modifying orders based on ability to pay, contacting noncustodial parents promptly after missed payments, updating guidelines for modern family dynamics, using automation for early noncompliance detection, and prioritizing consistent current support payments over uncollectible arrears. Effective modification processes can help ensure child support. Many observers believe that effective modification processes can help ensure child support orders remain appropriate and prevent the accumulation of inappropriate child support debt. States under the CSE program have flexibility in modifying and reviewing child support orders, with federal law requiring states to offer parents the opportunity to request a review every three years. Analysts suggest that child support modification laws should consider periods of incarceration, unemployment, or illness that may affect a noncustodial parent's ability to pay. Many low-income noncustodial parents face barriers that make it difficult to meet child support payments. In some cases, in-kind assistance like child care could be an alternative to incarceration for nonpayment. Research shows that father absence has negative effects on children, and some argue that incarceration as an enforcement remedy is no longer effective. Innovative approaches like probation and drug abuse prevention programs may be more beneficial. Approaches to confinement such as probation, drug abuse prevention programs, work and training programs, house arrest, or halfway house placement are effective alternatives to incarceration for nonviolent offenders. These measures help mitigate the negative impact of imprisonment on familial relationships and employment prospects. Non-incarceration remedies are seen as a better option for noncustodial parents, children, families, and communities, with potential cost savings that could be redirected towards funding alternative solutions, according to the Pew Center on the States. According to the Pew Center on the States, states are facing a fiscal crisis with corrections costs consuming a significant portion of state discretionary funds. Strategies like strengthening community supervision and reinvesting money spent on imprisoning low-risk inmates are being implemented to reduce costs and improve public safety. State and federal initiatives, such as responsible fatherhood programs and CSE access programs, aim to address the harmful impacts of father absence by providing job opportunities and skills training for noncustodial parents. Noncustodial parents with criminal records face barriers to employment due to background checks, making it difficult for them to meet child support obligations. Imposing jail time on low-income noncustodial parents is seen as counterproductive as it hinders their ability to work and earn money, exacerbating the issue. Noncustodial parents with criminal records face employment barriers and may be fired due to their past. Financial struggles post-release can lead to re-incarceration. Child support orders remain unchanged during incarceration, leading to arrears and interest accumulation. In some states, child support arrears are owed to the state, not the child or custodial parent, with no direct benefit to the child. These practices have significant long-term consequences on individuals. Noncustodial parents with criminal records may struggle to secure employment due to past incarceration and large debts, leading to re-incarceration for nonpayment of child support. Utilizing work or job training programs instead of jail time could benefit noncustodial parents and their children. Judges can mandate nonpaying noncustodial parents to participate in a work program if their child receives TANF benefits. Noncustodial parents can be mandated to participate in a TANF work program or pay child support, with the option of jail time for noncompliance. Programs like the Texas Noncustodial Parent Choices Program and Fathering Court offer alternatives to incarceration for noncustodial parents with child support arrears. Transitional Jobs programs also help noncustodial parents find employment. Some noncustodial parents participate in Transitional Jobs programs, providing wage-paying jobs, skill development, and supportive services to help them enter the labor force. State CSE programs partner with workforce development boards and courts to assist low-income noncustodial parents in meeting child support obligations. As of September 2011, 29 states and the District of Columbia operated work-oriented programs for noncustodial parents with CSE agency involvement. The text discusses the possibility of imposing mandatory work and training programs on low-income noncustodial parents who are unable to pay child support. It questions whether incarceration should be an option for parents who fail to comply with the program, emphasizing the importance of fulfilling financial obligations to support their children. The criminalization of nonpayment of child support is not coincidental, with all states and the District of Columbia having sanctions in place. In the 1990s, nonpayment of child support became a serious crime, leading to federal laws and state enforcement measures, including jail as a last resort option. State statutes classify offenses as nonsupport, abandonment, desertion, flagrant nonsupport, and criminal nonsupport, with penalties of up to six months in jail. The maximum penalties for nonpayment of child support vary by state, ranging from up to six months in jail in Rhode Island and the District of Columbia to a fine of up to $150,000 in Arizona and imprisonment between five and 20 years in Arkansas.
